topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: Using the Messaging Broker Service with ALS

body.p: The Messaging Broker Service provides on-demand RabbitMQ clusters and enables automatic access to the RabbitMQ management console. RabbitMQ is also available within ALS as a single-instance, unmanaged service. If your application relies on high message throughput or if you want to move an application from dev/test into production, you should strongly consider using the Messaging Broker Service instead of the RabbitMQ service embedded with ALS.

If the HPE Helion OpenStack cloud was configured with three availability zones, the Messaging Broker Service will automatically deploy the cluster across all three so that the cluster is resilient to server, VM, or availability zone failures.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: To use the Messaging Broker Service with ALS, you need to:

ol.li: Create a RabbitMQ cluster from the OpenStack Dashboard if a cluster does not already exist.
Once a cluster has been created, you can connect an application deployed to ALS with the Messaging Broker Service.

To connect, you must create an environment variable in the manifest.yml file of the application you wish to connect to the Messaging Broker Service. This will tell your application how to connect to the cluster using AMQP. The environment variable can be named anything you prefer. We will use MQ_URL in this example.
The connection string and MQ_URL value will look something like:amqps://username:password@ipaddress:5671/%2f
The username and password for a RabbitMQ cluster are the same credentials used to create the cluster.
Alternately, you can add other accounts to the cluster using the RabbitMQ management console. The RabbitMQ management console is accessible from the Horizon Management Console.
The new environment variable can then be inserted into a block within your manifest.yml file like so:env: MQ_URL: amqps://username:password@ipaddress:5671/%2f
You can then connect your application to the cluster by choosing from a long list of available AMQP client libraries. Your app will reference and parse the MQ_URL variable to connect to the cluster.

If you're using the Messaging Broker Service instead of the embedded unmanaged RabbitMQ service, you do not need to specify anything other than the environment variables in your manifest.yml file.
